headline: Treasury to Offer $56 Billion in Securities
summary: The Treasury plans to sell $56 billion on Monday in short-term bills.

headline: Mets Come Back on Pridie's Homer to Beat Dodgers; Yankees Beat Rangers
summary: A three-run home run by Jason Pridie in the sixth inning helped the Mets come from behind to beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 6-3, on Friday night.

headline: Quick Results
summary: None

headline: Blavatnik Gets All-Access Pass to Warner
summary: The high oil price may cause pain for Americans at the gas pump. But for those invested in Warner Music, it has its benefits.

headline: Road Rules for NYSE Investors
summary: Investors looking for clues on who will drive off with NYSE Euronext can learn from last year's dustup over Dollar Thrifty Automotive.

headline: ICICI Prudential AMC Invests in Residential Projects
summary: ICICI Prudential AMC has put in $17.9 million in a residential project in a Delhi suburb and plans to make a similar investment in a residential development in Bangalore from its first real-estate fund.

headline: President Tells Troops: 'Strategy Is Working'
summary: Obama capped a week of somber and sometimes celebratory events following the successful strike against bin Laden with a rally for U.S. troops.

headline: Greece Report Sparks Treasurys Demand
summary: A report that Greece may consider quitting the euro zone Friday sparked a rally in safe-haven Treasurys.

headline: A Ratings Jolt for Jakarta?
summary: Indonesian stocks are perkier than a cup of java. But with Asia twitchy about inflation, is it time investors woke up and smelled the coffee?

headline: Regulators Sue Arizona Over Union Law
summary: The NLRB filed suit against the state of Arizona, challenging the legality of a state constitutional amendment that requires workers to hold a secret-ballot election to decide whether to unionize a company.

headline: U.S. Closes Florida's Coastal Bank
summary: U.S. regulators announced the failure of a Florida bank, pushing the total number of bank failures in the U.S. this year to 40 and the number in Florida to five.

headline: Noonan: Show the Proof, Mr. President
summary: Americans don't want to 'spike the ball.' They want to show they crossed the goal line.

headline: Bowles Hopeful for 'Gang of Six' Deal
summary: Bowles said he was hopeful a bipartisan group of senators known as the "Gang of Six" would reach a deal next week to cut spending and overhaul the tax code.

headline: My Old Kentucky Home
summary: Louisville manages to be both genteel South and sensible Midwest. And every year for the Kentucky Derby, the north-central Kentucky town plays the gracious host who enjoys breaking out the seersucker and big hats and offering up mint juleps.

headline: From Fish to Plate: How Caviar is Made
summary: In California's Central Valley region, a group of entrepreneurial biologists and fish farmers have birthed a sustainable caviar industry. Here's a behind-the-scenes look at the harvesting, testing and packaging of caviar at the Sterling Caviar farm near Sacramento, Ca., and at nearby aquaculture farm, The Fishery.

headline: ECB Official: Don't See Us as Doves
summary: The ECB's anti-inflation resolve remains firm despite recent comments by ECB President Jean-Claude Trichet signaling that an interest-rate rise is unlikely in June, a top member of the ECB said in an interview.

headline: Region Shows Signs of Rebound
summary: New York and New Jersey continue to show signs that the regional economy is rebounding, but both states still face a number of uncertainties and challenges, officials with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said on Friday.

headline: Euro Plunges on Greece Report
summary: A report indicating Greece was considering bailing out of the euro zone pushed the euro to its second day of sharp declines.

headline: Euro-Zone Worries Block Commodity Rebound
summary: Fresh worries about the stability of Europe's economic union scuttled an early rebound in commodities, which had gained on upbeat U.S. jobs data.

headline: Deal Struck for Warner Music
summary: Billionaire Len Blavatnik has reached an agreement to buy Warner Music Group in a deal that values the company at around $3 billion.

headline: Railway Maps of the World
summary: A new book by Mark Ovenden, "Railway Maps of the World," (Viking) explores two hundred years of trains, from route guides, surveyor's maps, and travel posters.

headline: Brazil Top Court Approves Same-Sex Unions
summary: Brazil's Supreme Court ruled that same-sex couples share most - if not all - the same rights as married men and women in a landmark advance for the gay marriage movement in heavily Catholic Latin America.

headline: Obama on the Road
summary: President Obama traveled Friday to Indianapolis to speak on a cleaner and more secure energy future, and to Fort Campbell, Ky., to meet with the Navy SEAL team that executed the mission against Osama bin Laden.

headline: Rooms with an Attitude
summary: Peter Marino designs stores for some of the world's biggest luxury brand names, including Dior and Chanel

headline: Making Millions Out of Teddy Bears
summary: After years of working in retail, Maxine Clark set out to blaze her own path by founding Build-A-Bear Workshop.

headline: Unilever to Shed VO5, Rave Brands
summary: U.S. regulators reached a settlement with Unilever and Alberto Culver under which they will relinquish the Alberto VO5 and Rave hair-care brands to move forward with their $3.7 billion merger.

headline: Financial-Overhaul Law Only Equipped for 'Normal Crisis'
summary: Last year's financial-overhaul law hasn't solved the problem of how policymakers should deal with a crisis that threatens to take down the entire financial system, according to a former Treasury official who ran the bank bailout fund during the financial crisis.

headline: Lehman Creditors Buy Debt as Bankruptcy Case Moves On
summary: Three investment firms pursuing a rival creditor-payment plan for Lehman Brothers have purchased nearly $150 million in the failed bank's debt, bolstering their weight in the bankruptcy case.

headline: Dow Closes Up 54 Points
summary: Stocks pared gains from earlier in the session as worries over Greece limited the advance.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In Friday's pictures, young military cadets joke around in Russia, Angela Merkel plays with a penguin, policemen pull a man from the Trevi Fountain in Rome and more.

headline: Oil Below $100 Again
summary: Nymex crude-oil futures capped an aggressive week-long selloff with a 2.6% decline, aided by further strength in the dollar.

headline: Photos of the Day: May 6
summary: In today's pictures, young military cadets joke around in Russia, St. George's Day is celebrated in Kosovo, a penguin gets a famous visitor in Germany and more.

headline: Saudi Tied to '98 Bombings Could Be Extradited Soon
summary: A Saudi man who the U.S. has said previously acted as Osama bin Laden's public-relations representative could be extradited "within the next few months" from the U.K. to face criminal charges in the 1998 bombing of U.S. embassies in Africa.

headline: WellCare Profit More Than Triples
summary: WellCare's first-quarter earnings surged as the Medicaid and Medicare managed-care company reported increased membership and as the portion of premiums used to cover medical costs declined.

headline: Environmental Suits Threaten Gulf Drilling
summary: As oil and gas exploration in the western Gulf of Mexico resumes following the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, companies and federal regulators are facing a new reality: Environmentalists are gearing up for a legal fight.

headline: Gold Futures Gain
summary: Gold futures settled higher and silver pared steep losses as news of U.S. job creation renewed concerns about inflationary pressures.

headline: Copper Ends Below $4
summary: Copper futures settled at a five-month low as a plunge in the euro erased gains from stronger-than-forecast U.S. jobs figures.

headline: EU to Sanction 13 Syrian Officials
summary: European Union ambassadors agreed that the bloc should extend sanctions against 13 Syrian officials, not including President Bashar al-Assad. Sactions could be in place by the end of the week.

headline: Goldman Details Legal Tab
summary: Goldman Sachs spent more than $700 million on lawyers last year as it came under high-profile scrutiny, its chief counsel told shareholders.

headline: Delta Air Lines Seeks Job Cuts
summary: Delta Air Lines launched a round of voluntary buyouts in a bid to cut staff costs as it trims flying because of soaring jet fuel prices.

headline: Eddy Hartenstein Tapped for Tribune Co. Publisher Job
summary: The publisher of the Los Angeles Times said he would "foster an atmosphere of dialogue and ideas" at Tribune, which has been run by a four-person executive council since October.

headline: Europe Snaps Losing Streak; Nikkei Falls
summary: European markets snapped a three-session losing streak as gains in the banking sector and better-than-expected U.S. jobs data sparked a rally. In Asia, Japanese stocks fell after a three-day hiatus.

headline: A D.C. Race Where the Results Don't Matter
summary: The WSJ Washington Bureau runners competed in this year's Capital Challenge. Their teams: "Keeping up with the Dow Joneses" and "Running Dog Capitol-ists" finished somewhere in the back, but in good spirits nonetheless.

headline: Oil Prices Have Room for Rebound after Big Drop
summary: The rally in crude-oil futures isn't over yet, even after erasing seven weeks of gains in a single session.

headline: Schumer Tilts Toward German Offer for NYSE
summary: Sen. Schumer hasn't taken a public position on the competing bids for NYSE Euronext. But behind the scenes, he is leaning toward a surprising choice: the Germans.

headline: Consumer Groups Back Warren for CFPB
summary: Public-interest groups are pushing for Obama to appoint Elizabeth Warren director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, even as Republicans threaten to block any nominee.

headline: YRC Worldwide CEO, Interim CFO Likely To Step Down in July
summary: YRC Worldwide's CEO said both he and interim CFO William Trubeck likely will step down in late July, when the struggling trucking company aims to complete a financial restructuring.

headline: German School Confirms Politician's Plagiarism
summary: Germany's controversial ex-defense minister Karl-Theodor zu Guttenberg plagiarized swathes of his doctoral thesis "intentionally," according to the university that awarded him his doctorate.

headline: That bin Laden Letdown
summary: The news of the killing of Osama Bin Laden generated euphoria....for a New York minute.

headline: Europe Stocks Snap Losing Streak
summary: European markets snapped a three-session losing streak to end higher as gains in the banking sector and better-than-expected U.S. jobs data for April sparked a rally.

headline: Superior Industries International, Obagi Medical Products: Biggest Price Decliners (SUP, OMPI)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

headline: How to Hook a Prospect? Check Its Job Ads
summary: The key to figuring out what prospective clients need and securing their business is hidden in plain sight, says guest columnist Mike Michalowicz.

headline: Race, Politics and the Minimum Wage
summary: Minimum-wage proponents argue that a higher wage floor will improve the standard of living for poor families. The reality is that higher labor costs reduce employment, especially for young black men.

headline: The 50 Fastest-Growing Women-Led Firms
summary: Private U.S. businesses founded or led by women are making hefty financial strides, new research shows. Here's a list of top performers.

headline: Canada Employment Returns to Pre-Crisis Levels
summary: The Canadian labor market rebounded strongly in April, with 58,300 jobs created in the month after a slight loss in March, and full-time employment returning to levels last recorded at the start of the recession.

headline: A Preview Presidential Debate
summary: JOHN FUND ON THE TRAIL  There were two winners and a loser in last night's first debate among Republican presidential contenders in South Carolina. Call it a preview of coming attractions.

headline: Portugal's Banks Seek Stability
summary: Portugal's financial bailout will be tough for the country's banks, but they should be able to raise capital ratios without tapping aid, the heads of the main Portuguese banks said.

headline: Washington Post's Net Falls 66%
summary: Washington Post reported a 66% drop in quarterly profit, as enrollment sagged at its Kaplan education division.

headline: A Tale of Two U.K. Banks
summary: Results at Lloyds Banking Group and Royal Bank of Scotland highlight the differences in leadership at the two U.K. banks. Investors can now look ahead with more confidence to a post-turnaround RBS. The same cannot yet be said of Lloyds.

headline: Canada Deploys Troops to Help With Flooding
summary: Members of the Canadian armed forces deployed to help thousands of residents displaced by the worst flooding in Quebec in 150 years, amid record rainfall.

headline: Ripples From Commodity Rout May Be Limited
summary: The rout in commodity prices, driven by perceptions of softening global growth, has hit equities and boosted haven assets such as the dollar and bonds. But the setback may be only temporary.

headline: A Long-Brewing Takeover of Foster's
summary: Investors have been eyeing Australia's Foster's Group as the next major beer deal. But its shares may not trade low enough to let a bidder in.

headline: Alcatel-Lucent's Net Loss Narrows
summary: Alcatel-Lucent posted improved results in the first quarter, but concern over its dependence on the U.S. as its main growth driver hurt its shares even as it confirmed its full-year guidance.

headline: RBS's Loss Widens
summary: RBS's first-quarter loss widened from accounting charges and rising bad debts in Ireland, but its shares rose more than 3% as investors and analysts took comfort from improvements in the bank's core divisions.

headline: IAG's Pretax Loss Narrows
summary: International Consolidated Airlines Group S.A., the company formed through the merger between British Airways and Spain's Iberia, said its first-quarter fiscal losses narrowed and forecast significant growth in operating profit in 2011.

headline: Deutsche Telekom's Profit Falls
summary: Deutsche Telekom posted a 37% decline in first-quarter net profit as the company remained under pressure in many markets outside its home turf of Germany.

headline: Glencore IPO Orders Roll In
summary: Swiss commodity giant Glencore International so far has shrugged off the dive in commodity markets this week, with arranging banks saying orders are still pouring in for the $11 billion deal.

headline: Japan Watching Yen; No  Intervention Threats Yet
summary: Japan's finance minister said that he will carefully watch the rising yen, but stopped short of threatening currency market intervention, in a sign that it may take sharper gains in the currency to spur Japanese action.

headline: Tepco Offers Optimistic Cooling Plan
summary: Tepco said special cooling equipment will be in place at one of the reactors at the quake-hit Fukushima Daiichi nuclear complex by the end of the month, making the safe shutdown of the reactor a more-realistic prospect.

headline: ThyssenKrupp Shares Soar
summary: Shares in ThyssenKrupp rose sharply after the steelmaker announced a comprehensive reorganization of its business.

headline: New ThyssenKrupp Boss Shows His Steel
summary: Three months into the CEO job at ThyssenKrupp, Heinrich Hiesinger's planned sale or spin-off of assets responsible for a fifth of its revenues would transform the German steel and engineering giant.

headline: New York Photos of the Day
summary: In today's photos from New York, President Obama visited Ground Zero, Mets shortstop Jose Reyes celebrated a victory over San Francisco and the New York Giants held practice in Hoboken, N.J.

headline: India's Nuclear Power Corp. Pushing for Projects
summary: State-run Nuclear Power Corp. of India is working to allay the concerns of the Gujarat state government, where it plans to set up nuclear reactors made by GE Hitachi, and is trying to get regulatory clearances for its coastal project in southern India.

headline: U.S., China Agree On 'Direction of Reform' for Yuan
summary: The U.S. and China agree on the "direction of reform" for the yuan exchange rate, but with a different focus, China's vice finance minister said.

headline: SKS Microfinance Slumps to Quarterly Loss
summary: SKS Microfinance slumped to a fourth quarter net loss of 697.7 million rupees ($15.59 million) from a net profit of 628.9 million rupees a year earlier, dragged by a surge in provisions.

headline: State-Run Power Finance Sets Follow-On Offer
summary: The Indian government set the indicative price of Power Finance's follow-on public offering in a range of 193 rupees ($4.3) – 203 rupees a share.

headline: Japanese Yields Drop
summary: Yields in Japan fell to multimonth lows as the Golden Week holidays came to an end.

headline: India This Week
summary: Gujarat and Maharashtra celebrated their 50th anniversaries, Indians reacted to the news of Osama bin Laden's death, voters at the West Bengal elections and more.

headline: BASF's Profit Doubles
summary: BASF, the world's biggest chemicals company, backed its forecast for "significant sales growth" this year as it reported that its first-quarter net profit more than doubled from a year earlier on stronger sales volumes.

headline: Hearings Resume in Indian Telecom Case
summary: An India court will continue hearing Monday the bail pleas filed by five corporate executives allegedly involved in rigging the sale of telecom licenses in 2008, while a lower court will resume hearing Saturday a related case that implicates a lawmaker in the scandal.

headline: Piramal Healthcare Forays into Financial Services
summary: Piramal Healthcare's board on Friday approved the company's move into the financial services sector by clearing the acquisition of two asset management firms for a total of $50 million.

headline: Weak Jobs Data Could Put Final Nail in Rally's Coffin
summary: Disappointing jobs data this morning could revive the Wall Street adage "sell in May and go away," analysts say.

headline: Oil's Drop Tests Russia's Budget
summary: Russia's ability to balance its $375 billion budget has come under threat after a sharp drop in crude prices, especially since the Kremlin plans on boosting spending during a year of parliamentary elections.

headline: South Korea Reshuffles Cabinet
summary: South Korean President Lee Myung-bak will replace five ministers in his cabinet in a response to defeats for his ruling party in recent by-elections for parliamentary seats.

headline: U.K. Election Results Reassuring for Gilts
summary: Investors can cross off one of the major risks to the current bullish mood: the coalition government is not about to fall apart—and even if it did, the poor performance of the Labour party suggests it is in no position to win an election.

headline: Election Rhetoric Raises Tensions With Kurds
summary: Election violence and political rhetoric increased tensions with the Kurdish minority in Turkey, as Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan accused the main Kurdish political party of involvement in an attack on his campaign convoy.

headline: India Shares Snap Nine-Day Losing Run
summary: Indian shares snapped their longest losing streak in a decade as a sharp fall in crude prices triggered a bout of short-covering in battered large-cap stocks, particularly in the banking and auto sectors.

headline: Kia Expects to Increase Market Share
summary: Driven in particular by strong demand for its cars in the U.S., Kia Motors Corp. expects to grab a significantly larger slice of the global automobile market this year, a senior executive said.

headline: India's Bumper Wheat Crop
summary: India's record wheat crop this year may encourage the country to re-enter the export market after a five-year absence.

headline: Commodity Slide Drags Down Asia Shares
summary: Asian stock markets ended mostly lower, with commodity-related stocks battered after oil and metals prices dropped sharply Thursday following weaker-than-expected U.S. jobless-claims data.

headline: Constellation Energy's Profit Drops
summary: Constellation Energy's first-quarter profit fell 63% as costs increased and revenue slipped.

headline: Gold Demand Rises On India Auspicious Day
summary: Jewelry shops opened early in parts of India as people lined up outside to buy gold during Akshaya Tritiya, a Hindu festival considered auspicious to buy bullion, but demand for silver remained low as edgy investors eyed further price falls in the white metal.

headline: Look Beyond Costs for Best Holiday Deals
summary: When planning for your upcoming summer holidays, weigh the costs involved versus the experience you may get, says Shefali Anand, India personal finance writer.

headline: German Industrial Production Jumps
summary: German industrial production climbed more than expected in March, data showed, as steady growth continues for Europe's largest economy.

headline: India Adviser Cuts Growth Estimate
summary: The top economic adviser to the Indian prime minister has cut his estimate on the country's growth by half a percentage point, citing high inflation, and warned that ballooning subsidies will be a risk to the government's budget deficit target.

headline: Muthoot Finance Off to a Strong Start
summary: Shares of Muthoot Finance began trading Friday with a 2.9% premium to their initial public offering price on the Bombay Stock Exchange.

headline: Rabindranath Tagore's 150th Birth Anniversary
summary: India celebrates the 150th birth anniversary of Nobel laureate Rabindranath Tagore on Saturday. Here is a look at his work and life, in pictures.

headline: U.K. Producer Prices Surge
summary: U.K. factory-gate prices rose faster than expected in April, pushed higher by a record increase in clothes prices.

headline: IPL Roundup
summary: Kochi Tuskers Kerala beat Kolkata Knight Riders by 17 runs and Delhi Daredevils beat the Deccan Chargers by four wickets thanks to a century by Virender Sehwag.

headline: Dangling from hoops and ropes, in tights
summary: Aerial acrobatics isn't a common activity among finance professionals, but James Barrett takes ownership of it.

headline: Kirin Books Post-Quake Loss
summary: Kirin Holdings swung into the red in the first quarter due to a special loss related to a quake-damaged brewery in northern Japan.

headline: Youku.com Net Loss Narrows
summary: Chinese online-video company Youku.com said its net loss narrowed in the first quarter. The company is also looking to increase its capital reserves.

headline: EU Hopes to Sign Trade Pact With Singapore in 2011
summary: The European Union hopes to complete one free trade pact with a Southeast Asian nation in 2011 and the most likely partner is Singapore, EU Trade Commissioner Karel De Gucht said.

headline: Commerzbank Confirms Earnings
summary: Commerzbank confirmed first-quarter earnings figures pre-announced earlier this week and reiterated its forecast for the full year, saying that recent positive trends continued in April.

headline: Jindal Steel Undecided on Date of Unit's IPO
summary: NEW DELHI -- Jindal Steel & Power hasn't yet decided on a date for a planned initial public offering of its power-generation unit despite the looming deadline of May 27.

headline: FX Call 07:15 GMT Hourly News Briefing
summary: -- The RBA says it will probably have to raise rates again "at some point," upping its December core inflation forecast to 3.0%, the top of its target band, from 2.75%.

headline: India in Pictures
summary: The Air India strike, India's wheat harvesting season, Indian Premier League matches and more.

headline: Gadhafi Stages Event to Show Libyan Tribal Unity
summary: But what the government billed as a nationwide show of support drew only limited participation.

headline: Australia Central Bank Signals Higher Rates Ahead
summary: Australia's central bank signaled its intent to raise interest rates in coming months to confront rising inflation, despite softness in parts of the economy harmed by a high Australian dollar.

headline: India Monsoon Likely to Arrive On Time
summary: India's crucial monsoon rains are progressing well, according to early signs, and are likely to reach the country's Andaman and Nicobar Islands by their usual date of May 20.

headline: Candidate Q&A: Chen Show Mao
summary: Chen Show Mao, a partner in the Beijing office of law firm Davis Polk & Wardwell, was billed as the Workers' Party's "star catch" upon his return to Singapore to contest this year's elections.

headline: Morning News Roundup
summary: News roundup from Indian newspapers, news wires and Web sites on Friday, May 6, 2011. Deals India has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

headline: Pricey Pact
summary: Mundra Port and Special Economic Zone's winning of a 99-year lease of a coal terminal in Australia is an expensive deal and how the company will pay for it is a big concern, writes Pallavi Pengonda in Mint's Mark to Market column.

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for May 6, 2011

headline: On-Site Safety-Inspector Rule Gets a Second Look
summary: The Department of Buildings recently said that safety inspectors can be employees of the contracting companies performing major facade work.

headline: Casino Deal Gets a Boost
summary: A long-stalled plan to transform a legendary Catskills hotel into a $600 million casino got a boost after the Westchester developer, Louis Cappelli, reached a partnership agreement with the operators of the Mohegan Sun Casino in Connecticut.

headline: Garry Rodan: Singapore's 'Accountability Election'
summary: The opposition pitches a new style of democratic oversight, and voters seem to like it.

headline: Old Kentucky With a Twist
summary: Hoteliers update a 1,000-acre farm that predates the Civil War.

headline: Violin, Flute for the Kitchen
summary: For a celebration of an art institution as supposedly outlandish as the Kitchen, the entertainment at its 40th anniversary gala at Capitale was surprisingly conservative.

headline: HSBC Plots New Strategy
summary: HSBC Holdings new chief executive, Stuart Gulliver, will announce a strategic revamp next week aimed at unlocking the potential of a bank seen as a "sleeping giant."

headline: Avon Bribery-Probe Worries Hurt Share Price
summary: Avon shares fell sharply amid fresh concerns over a widening bribery investigation.

headline: Tough Chick, Tender Chickens
summary: USA's "In Plain Sight" showcases a blond federal marshal with more guts than charm, while Ovation's "In Search of Food" and a PBS documentary about the making of "The Bonesetter's Daughter" opera offer sustenance for the body and for the soul. Nancy deWolf Smith reviews.

headline: Europe Hits Pause on Rates
summary: European Central Bank President Jean-Claude Trichet signaled a temporary pause in the ECB's path toward higher interest rates, a sign of caution as officials confront mounting problems along Europe's periphery.

headline: Remembering the Harpsichord Heroine
summary: An exhibition at the Bach House in Eisenach, Germany, shows how Polish harpsichordist Wanda Landowska has influenced how we appreciate Bach's music.

headline: China Miéville, Literary Shape-Shifter
summary: The British novelist jumps genres again in his new novel, "Embassytown."

headline: Limping to Photo Finish
summary: Rarely has there been a year when all England's top clubs have shown themselves to be so flawed all at the same time.

headline: News Corp.'s IGN Buys Gaming Site UGO
summary: News Corp.'s IGN videogame network is buying rival UGO Entertainment from Hearst. News Corp. is considering a spin-off of IGN.

headline: Germany's Moral Warriors
summary: The country's great and good recoil from the killing of bin Laden.

headline: Face to Face With Masters of the Portrait
summary: "About Face: Portraiture as Subject" opens at the Blanton Museum of Art at the University of Texas at Austin.

headline: Ai Weiwei Retrospective
summary: The first retrospective in the U.K. of Ai Weiwei's work comes at a poignant time, with the whereabouts of the Chinese dissident artist still unknown after he was detained last month by authorities at Beijing Airport.

headline: Cool in Cambodia
summary: Belgian photographer John Vink spent years splitting his time between Europe and Southeast Asia, shooting photographs of refugees in war-torn countries. Since 2000, he's traveled a little less—going between Cambodia's capital, Phnom Penh, and the sleepy coastal town of Kep. But in early 2009, he decided to build a permanent place in the hills outside Kep.

headline: Al Qaeda Sought to Target Trains
summary: Notes picked up by the Navy SEALs who killed bin Laden prompted a warning of potential al Qaeda threats to U.S. trains.

headline: The Short List: Warren Haynes's 'Man in Motion'
summary: Plus, Thomas Perry's "The Informant," and "By the Way, Meet Vera Stark" opens Off Broadway.

headline: Race Out of Risky Assets Lifts Treasurys
summary: Downbeat economic data led investors to further question the pace of economic growth, sending them into the comparative safety of U.S. government bonds as they fled an array of riskier assets.

headline: Film Review: 'Thor'
summary: Like Thor's hammer, this ersatz epic bludgeons its victims into submission, says Joe Morgenstern. Meanwhile, "The Beaver" deprives us of any sense of discovery, but still fits Mel Gibson like a glove.

headline: Expect Fed to Hum Same Old Tune
summary: When forced to choose between moral and economic hazard, the Fed repeatedly has opted for the former. If markets again become unglued, its reaction is unlikely to be different.

headline: Pakistani Pique
summary: General Kayani strikes back.

headline: Experts: bin Laden Killing Was Legal
summary: Many U.S. legal experts hold firm that the White House was on solid legal footing for its strike teams to carry out the Pakistani raid that killed Osama bin Laden as well as similar attacks against al Qaeda members abroad in recent years.

headline: Stock Exchanges and Sarbox
summary: One reason the NYSE likes the idea of a foreign merger partner.

headline: 'Doctor Who' and 'Home Improvement'
summary: Next week's releases of past television series.

headline: IPOs, M&A Deals Spawn New Rich
summary: Giant initial public offerings and a surge in mergers and acquisitions are spawning a new generation of billionaires and millionaires.

headline: What's on Around Europe
summary: The Weekend Journal's guide to exhibitions, concerts and events across Europe.

headline: Gap Design Executive to Leave
summary: Gap said global design executive Patrick Robinson is leaving, and the apparel retailer gave a downbeat forecast. His departure was yet another sign of Gap's failure to breathe new life into its namesake brand.

headline: Galleon Jury Hears More Calls
summary: Jurors in the insider-trading trial of Galleon Group founder Raj Rajaratnam again focused Thursday on a series of secretly recorded phone calls in which Mr. Rajaratnam allegedly shared or received inside information.
